description: Chocolat Meilleure and Vanilla Mieux are two witches who are pitched in a contest to see who will become the new Queen of the Witch World. They must travel to the Human World and collect the hearts of humans. Whoever collects the most "human hearts" wins. Even though they're rivals, the two are still best friends. Join them on this adventure!
synonyms: Chocola et Vanilla - Sugar Sugar Rune

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Shoujo
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult females.

tags.name: Witch
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a witch.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Royal Affairs
tags.description: Features nobility, alliances, arranged marriage, succession disputes, religious orders and other elements of royal politics.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Shapeshifting
tags.description: Features character(s) who changes one's appearance or form.

tags.name: Age Gap
tags.description: Prominently features romantic relations between people with a significant age difference.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: Matriarchy
tags.description: Prominently features a country that is ruled by a Queen or a society that is dominated by female inheritance.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Ojou-sama
tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

tags.name: Isekai
tags.description: Features characters being transported into an alternate world setting and having to adapt to their new surroundings.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Estranged Family
tags.description: At least one family member of the MC intentionally distances themselves or a family distances themselves from a person related to the MC.

tags.name: Curses
tags.description: Features a character, object or area that has been cursed, usually by a malevolent supernatural force.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Tennis
tags.description: Centers around the sport of tennis.

tags.name: Athletics
tags.description: Centers around sporting events that involve competitive running, jumping, throwing, or walking.

tags.name: Anthropomorphism
tags.description: Contains non-human character(s) that have attributes or characteristics of a human being.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Desert
tags.description: Prominently features a desert environment.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Skeleton
tags.description: Prominently features skeleton(s) as a character.

tags.name: Fairy
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a fairy.

tags.name: Dungeon
tags.description: Prominently features a dungeon environment.

tags.name: Fencing
tags.description: Centers around the sport of fencing.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

name.native: メイユール ショコラ
ピエール・タンペート・ド・ネージュ

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

Yoshida has written and supervised numerous scripts for anime series, live-action dramas and films. Her major works include [Kaleido Star](https://anilist.co/anime/427), [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477), [Maria-sama ga Miteru](https://anilist.co/anime/158), [D.Gray-man](https://anilist.co/anime/1482), [K-On!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680), [Bakuman](https://anilist.co/anime/7674) and [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131). In more recent works, she has supervised the screenplays for [Majestic Prince](https://anilist.co/anime/15863), [Non Non Biyori](https://anilist.co/anime/17549), [A Town Where You Live](https://anilist.co/anime/17741), [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417), [Yowamushi Pedal](https://anilist.co/anime/18179) and [Castle Town Dandelion](https://anilist.co/anime/20951). In films, she wrote the screenplay for Ghibli's [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597), the original films that would make up [Digimon: The Movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2961), Kyoto Animation’s hit anime film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954), and the film adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's [Buddha](https://anilist.co/anime/7014), the last one's [second film](https://anilist.co/anime/20500) was given a stamp of approval by the Dalai Lama.

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. In 2018, she wrote the screenplay for [Violet Evergarden](https://anilist.co/anime/21827) which aired on TV in Japan and is licensed by Netflix.

Yoshida also wrote the story for the manga series [Tokyo Mew Mew](https://anilist.co/manga/30554).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

In films, she wrote the screenplay for Ghibli's [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597), the original films that would make up [Digimon: The Movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2961), Kyoto Animation’s hit anime film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954), and the film adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's [Buddha](https://anilist.co/anime/7014), the last one's [second film](https://anilist.co/anime/20500) was given a stamp of approval by the Dalai Lama.

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. In 2018, she wrote the screenplay for [Violet Evergarden](https://anilist.co/anime/21827) which aired on TV in Japan and is licensed by Netflix.

Yoshida also wrote the story for the manga series [Tokyo Mew Mew](https://anilist.co/manga/30554).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/anno_moyoco)

She is a manga artist and fashion writer, with numerous books published in both categories. Her manga and books have attained considerable popularity among young women in Japan. Though she primarily writes manga of the josei genre, her most popular series, [Sugar Sugar Rune](https://anilist.co/manga/30429/), (serialized in Nakayoshi) is targeted primary at school-aged girls. In a recent Oricon poll, she was voted the number eight most popular manga artist among females and thirteen in the general category. Her manga [Happy Mania](https://anilist.co/manga/30354/) was made into a television series in 1998, followed by [Hataraki Man](https://anilist.co/manga/33068/) in October 2007. [Sakuran](https://anilist.co/manga/32061/) was made into a movie in 2006. Moyoko is married to famous anime director [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/). Their relationship is portrayed in her autobiographical manga [Kantoku Fuyuki Todoki](https://anilist.co/manga/49393/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/anno_moyoco)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋ナツコ)

_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/193091/)._
Kouichi Oohata is a director and mecha designer best known for creating the Gunbuster from *Top wo Nerae!*
Kouichi Oohata is a director and mecha designer best known for creating the Gunbuster from *Top wo Nerae!*
A Japanese anime director, storyboard artist, and animator.
A Japanese anime director, storyboard artist, and animator.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sushio_) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/sushiogumicompany/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%81%99%E3%81%97%E3%81%8A)

Ishizaki Toshio, better known as Sushio, is an animator, illustrator and character designer working for [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/).

After graduating from Yoyogi Animation Academy, he joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). He debuted as an in-betweener in [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/), as a key animator on [Berserk](https://anilist.co/anime/33/), and as an animation director on [Mahoromatic](https://anilist.co/anime/276/). In 2007, he served as a character designer for the first time on [Kiss Dum: Engage Planet](https://anilist.co/anime/2106/). He was a key staff member at Gainax for a long time, but left in 2011 when [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/) and others established the anime production company Trigger. There he was given the job of handling the character designs for [Kill la Kill](https://anilist.co/anime/18679/), the first TV series produced by the newly-found studio.

Specializes in action and effects, and his skills attract a lot of attention in the industry.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/931752627359977472)

Currently mainly active at [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/).

Yoshigaki joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) after graduating from Yoyogi Animation School. There he immediately got along with fellow animator [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/), who joined the studio at the same time. Imaishi says that Yoshigaki is the "ideal animator."

__Alma mater:__ Osaka University of Arts

Hiromitsu Kanazawa is a director formerly belonging to Satelight, now affiliated with GoHands.

Maruo Miho is a screenwriter for anime and a member of the Writers Guild of Japan.

Her first steps as screenwriter were done on episodes of the popular anime Sazae-san and Doraemon in 1983. At that time she credited herself with her real name but switched to the current variant shortly after.

Most of her work revolves around shoujo shows, such as Mahou Tsukai Sally and Kodocha. Her debut as series composer was on the second season of Shounen Ashibe in 1992. She often works together with other female Writers Guild members, such as Reiko Yoshida and Mamiko Ikeda.
Kouichi Oohata is a director and mecha designer best known for creating the Gunbuster from *Top wo Nerae!*
